extracted_info.summary: 76-year-old female with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, colon cancer, thoracic aortic aneurysm, and prediabetes who sustained a left intertrochanteric hip fracture after a mechanical fall. Patient is scheduled for ORIF with cephalomedullary nail.
diagnosis: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of left breast
key_information: Patient has history of right THA and left TKA
Patient ambulates without assistive device at baseline
Osteoporosis labs ordered (1,25-vitamin D, intact PTH, and ionized Calcium)
Non-weight bearing on left lower extremity
DVT prophylaxis with HSQ pre-op
Medicine consult requested for pre-operative risk stratification
Allergies to Ragweed and Nitrofuran analogues
Surgeon recommends spinal anesthesia and early care to reduce perioperative morbidity and mortality
Patient has thoracic aortic aneurysm (4.2cm) which may impact anesthesia risk
Patient has history of colon cancer and is part of PACES clinical trial

procedure: Intramedullary Nailing of Left Intertrochanteric Femur Fracture
extracted_info.summary: 76-year-old female with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and colon cancer who suffered a mechanical fall resulting in a left intertrochanteric femur fracture. The patient underwent intramedullary nailing of the left intertrochanteric femur fracture using an Arthrex short nail implant system. The procedure involved closed reduction, insertion of a 10mm x 20cm x 125deg short trochanteric nail, a 10.5mm x 90mm telescoping lag screw, and a 5.0mm x 38mm cortical screw. Patient is weight-bearing as tolerated postoperatively.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

Barrie, Patricia H (MR # MR3451845) DOB: 09/02/1949
Pelvis: No pain or instability with AP or lateral compression

All other large joints in the extremities were palpated and ranged with no signs of deformity or pain.

Imaging / studies:
XR AP pelvis + femur demonstrates Left intertrochanteric hip fracture

Impression and plan:

Patricia H Barrie is a 76 y.o. female sustained a left intertrochanteric hip fracture. Femur fractures in the elderly are of
the highest severity due to the morbidity without treatment and risk of death due to bed-ridden disability, risk of
ulcers, and risk of clot and other medical complications causing death. Therefore | had a long discussion with the
patient and their family about the treatment options, including nonoperative and operative intervention. We
discussed risks and benefits and alternatives to fixation as well as chances of full or partial weight bearing after. After
going over these options, we decided to pursue left hip ORIF with a cephalomedullary nail.

We discussed the risks of surgery including infection, wound complications, bleeding, need for a transfusion, possible
damage to surronding neurovascular structures, potential for continued pain, continued weakness, worsening pain
and worsening weakness, stiffness, instability/dislocation, limb length discrepancy, fracture, infection requiring the
resection or revision, component loosening or cutout and the need for conversion surgery in the future. We also
discussed the risks of thromboembolic complications, stroke, heart attack, cardiac event, heart failure, pulmonary
edema, fat/cement embolus, aspiration, death, and the risks of anesthesia and nerve blocks.

Awaiting primary medical service optimization and clearance. Would favor spinal anesthesia and early care as delay
in care results in perioperative morbidity and mortality with geriatric femur fractures.

- osteoporosis labs (1,25-vitamin D, intact PTH, and ionized Calcium)
- NPO/IVF for OR in AM

Patient Name: Patricia H Barrie

Date of Procedure: 11/10/25

Location: Greenwich Hospital

MRN: MR3451845

Procedure: Intramedullary Nailing of Left Intertrochanteric Femur Fracture
Suggested cpt code: 27245

Preliminary Diagnosis: Left intertrochanteric Femur Fracture, displaced
Postoperative Diagnosis: Same

Surgeon: Dr. Michael B Held
First Assist: None

Indication:

The patient is a 76 y.o. female with past medical history of htn, hld, hypothy, colon ca who suffered a mechanical fall
on 11/9/25. The patient was brought to the Greenwich Hospital Emergency Room, where they were found to have a
left hip pertrochanteric femur fracture. The patient uses no assistive device for ambulating at baseline. She has a
prior right hip replacement and left knee replacement at HSS a few years ago.

| had a long discussion with the patient and family regarding treatment options for her left proximal femur fracture,
and | did recommend surgical repair. We discussed the risks, benefits and alternatives. Nonoperative treatment will
result in prolonged recumbency, non-weight bearing to the right lower extremity, and potentially bedsores, DVT,
pneumonia, persistent pain, limited mobility, displacement of fracture, fracture non-union, fracture malunion, or
deformity. The risks, benefits, and alternatives of surgery were discussed. The risks of surgery include, but not limited
to, pain, bleeding, stiffness, infection, damage to nearby structures, blood vessel injury, nerve injury, tendon injury,
failure of fixation, hardware failure, hardware complications, soft tissue irritation secondary to hardware, peri-implant
fractures, fracture non-union, fracture malunion, fracture displacement, limb deformity, scar formation, post-traumatic
arthritis, the need for additional surgery, thromboembolic complications, stroke, heart attack, cardiac event, heart

Barrie, Patricia H (MRN MR3451845) Printed by Stagno, Cesarina [767] at 11/12/2025 10:22 AM 1/3

11/12/25, 10:22 AM Barrie, Patricia H (MR # MR3451845) DOB: 09/02/1949

failure, pulmonary edema, fat embolus, aspiration, death, and the risks of anesthesia. The potential benefits of
surgery are pain relief or improvement, fracture stability, improved mobility, and allowance of immediate weight
bearing post-operatively. We did discuss that we may need to perform an open reduction of the fracture to manually
manipulate the fracture fragments, in order to improve the alignment of the fracture prior to internal fixation. The
patient expressed understanding and elected to proceed with operative fixation of the left proximal femur fracture with
a cephalomedullary nail.

We also discussed the overall poor prognosis for patients who have suffered a femur fracture, with high morbidity and
mortality rates following this particular pattern of injury. The patient and family expressed understanding and elected
to proceed with operative fixation of the proximal femur fracture.

The patient was seen by the Medicine service and was determined to be optimized from a medical standpoint for this
surgery. The medicine team cleared the patient for surgery as well.

Procedure:

The patient was brought to the Operating Room and after the successful induction of general anesthesia, a closed
reduction was performed. Flouroscopy was used to confirm that the reduction was within acceptable parameters. The
left lower extremity was then prepped and draped in the usual sterile manner with the patient in the supine position
on the fracture table. Prophylactic antibiotics were administered within 30 minutes prior to the procedure as well as 1
gram of tranexamic acid. A time out was performed by all members of the surgical team confirming patient identity
and surgical site laterality.

A lateral incision was made proximal to, and in-line with, the femur. The entry guidewire was then advanced onto the
appropriate start site on the greater trochanter. This was confirmed with intraoperative flouroscopy on both the AP
and lateral views. The guidewire was then advanced with power into the intramedullary canal. Again flouroscopy was
used to confirm that the entry guidewire was in the appropriate position. The entry reamer was then used through the
soft tissue protector canula. Flouroscopy was used to confirm appropriate position of the entry reamer within the
intramedullary canal and that it had been advanced to a sufficient depth. The reamer and entry guidewire were then
removed.

The nail was then carefully advanced over the guidewire. During advancement of the nail, all reduction maneuvers
were employed to maintain the reduction during insertion of the nail. Flouroscopy was again used to confirm that the
nail had been advanced to the appropriate depth. The long guidewire was then removed. An incision was made over
the lateral aspect of the thigh and the cannula for the lag screw was advanced until it made contact with the lateral
cortical bone. Using flouroscopic guidance, the guidewire for the lag screw was then inserted and confirmed to be in
appropriate position with the guidwire center-center on AP and lateral views of the femoral head. The depth of the
guidewire was then measured and the 90 mm left threaded lag screw selected. The guidewire was then overdrilled
and tapped for the screw of the appropriate depth. The lag screw was then inserted to the appropriate depth which
again confirmed using flouroscopy.

We then turned our attention to insertion of the distal interlocking screw. A small incision was made over the lateral
thigh in line with the cannula for the distal interlocking screw. The cannula was then advanced through the incision
and down to bone. The drill was then carefully advanced and the depth of the interlocking screw measured off of the
drill at 38mm. The screw of appropriate length was then inserted. Flouroscopy was again used to confirm that the
screws were in appropriate position.

The wounds were then copiously irrigated. The fascia was closed with interrupted 0 vicryl suture. The deep
subcutaneous layers were closed with interrupted 0 vicryl and the dermal layer with 3-0 vicryl. The skin was then
closed with staples. Sterile dressings were then applied and the patient was awaken from anesthesia. The patient
was transferred to the recovery room in stable condition. All sponge and instrument counts were correct.

Arthrex short nail implant system was used for this procedure

Postop Plan

The patient will be WBAT. DVT prophylaxis will be started with asa 81bid the morning of POD1; additional DVT
prophylaxis will include SCDs, compression stockings, progressive mobilization. They will receive 24 hours of
postoperative antibiotics. The patient will be discharged from the hospital when they are medically stable, have met
all PT goals, and their pain is well controlled with oral analgesia.

Dr. Michael B. Held

[AI ADDED: ASSESSMENT AND PLAN SECTION]
Impression and Plan:
Patricia H Barrie is a 76-year-old female who sustained a left intertrochanteric hip fracture. Femur fractures in the elderly are of the highest severity due to the morbidity without treatment and risk of death due to bed-ridden disability, risk of ulcers, and risk of clot and other medical complications causing death. 

[AI ADDED: Medical necessity documentation] The patient requires surgical intervention due to:
1. Displaced intertrochanteric hip fracture confirmed on imaging
2. Inability to ambulate
3. Risk of significant morbidity and mortality with non-operative management
4. Previously independent ambulatory status
5. Medical optimization for surgical intervention

I had a long discussion with the patient and their family about the treatment options, including nonoperative and operative intervention. We discussed risks and benefits and alternatives to fixation as well as chances of full or partial weight bearing after. After going over these options, we decided to pursue left hip ORIF with a cephalomedullary nail.

We discussed the risks of surgery including infection, wound complications, bleeding, need for a transfusion, possible damage to surrounding neurovascular structures, potential for continued pain, continued weakness, worsening pain and worsening weakness, stiffness, instability/dislocation, limb length discrepancy, fracture, infection requiring the resection or revision, component loosening or cutout and the need for conversion surgery in the future. We also discussed the risks of thromboembolic complications, stroke, heart attack, cardiac event, heart failure, pulmonary edema, fat/cement embolus, aspiration, death, and the risks of anesthesia.

Procedure planned: Left hip open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) with cephalomedullary nail

procedure: Intramedullary Nailing of Left Intertrochanteric Femur Fracture
extraction_data.summary: 76-year-old female with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and colon cancer who suffered a mechanical fall resulting in a left intertrochanteric femur fracture. The patient underwent intramedullary nailing of the left intertrochanteric femur fracture using an Arthrex short nail implant system. The procedure involved closed reduction, insertion of a 10mm x 20cm x 125deg short trochanteric nail, a 10.5mm x 90mm telescoping lag screw, and a 5.0mm x 38mm cortical screw. Patient is weight-bearing as tolerated postoperatively.
